newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU silent on Kohl's call for German EU payment cut.
newsitem.headline: EU silent on Kohl's call for German EU payment cut.

text.p: The European Commission declined to comment on Monday on a call by German Chancellor Helmut Kohl that his country's payments to the European Union should be cut.
"We are aware of what Chancellor Kohl said but we have no comment to make," Commission spokesman Joao Vale de Almeida told reporters.
Kohl said in an interview released on Sunday that Germany's payments to the EU were too high.
"The current payment level from Germany is too high, that's undisputed. And we must work to bring down this sum," Kohl said.

The size of Germany's contributons to the EU has leapt to the top of the German political agenda over the past few months, with senior figures in all major parties complaining Bonn can not afford to pay the lion's share of the EU budget.
Germany is by far the largest contributor to EU coffers.
The issue of EU financing is next due to be discussed in 1999, when the bloc will have to work out a new formula to take account of planned enlargement to include new members.
However, the Commission proposed last month that the payment structure be left virtually unchanged until the year 2006.
